facts.text: Allahabad High Court by judgment and order dated November 11, 1971 in Civil Misc. Writ Nos. 3716 of 1970 held provisions of section 29-A of the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948 (inserted by section 15 of U.P. Sales Tax Amendment and Validation Act, 1971) and section 17 of the Amending Act unconstitutional.
Supreme Court in Commissioner of Sales Tax v. Ganga Sugar Corporation Ltd. held section 8-A(4) of principal Act ultra vires the State Legislature.

Section 8-A(4) provided: Without prejudice to the provisions of clause (g) of sub-section (2) of section 14, the amount realised by any person as tax on sale of any goods shall, notwithstanding anything contained in any other provision of this Act, be deposited by him in a Government treasury within such period as may be prescribed, if the amount so realised exceeds the amount payable as tax in respect of that sale or if no tax is payable in respect thereof.

Supreme Court in above case relied on Abdul Quader and Co. v. Sales Tax Officer, Hyderabad, holding similar provision in Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act (section 11(2)) invalid as not under entry 54 List II.

In 1969, U.P. Taxation Amendment Act, 1969 (U.P. Act 11 of 1969) inserted section 29-A: Refund in special cases. Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act or in any other law for the time being in force or in any judgment, decree or order of any court, where any amount is either deposited or paid by any dealer or other person under sub-section (4) or sub-section (5) of section 8-A, such amount or any part thereof shall on a claim being made in that behalf in such form and within such period as may be prescribed, be refunded to the person from whom such dealer or the person had actually realised such amount or part, and to no other person.
U.P. Sales Tax Amendment and Validation Act, 1971 published on August 22, 1971. Section 10 omitted sub-sections (4) and (5) of section 8-A.

Section 15 of Amending Act substituted new section 29-A: (1) Where any amount is realised from any person by any dealer purporting to do so by way of realisation of tax on the sale of any goods to such person, such dealer shall deposit the entire amount so realised into the Government Treasury, within such period as may be prescribed notwithstanding that the dealer is not liable to pay such amount as tax or that only a part of it is due from him as tax under this Act. (2) Any amount deposited by any dealer under sub-section (1) shall, to the extent it is not due as tax, be held by the State Government in trust for the person from whom it was realised by the dealer, or for his legal representatives, and the deposit shall discharge such dealer of the liability in respect thereof to the extent of the deposit. (3) Where any amount is deposited by any dealer under sub-section (1), such amount or any part thereof shall, on a claim being made in that behalf in such form as may be prescribed, be refunded, in the manner prescribed, to the person from whom such dealer had actually realised such amount or part, or to his legal representatives, and to no other person. Provided that no such claim shall be entertained after the expiry of three years from the date of the order of assessment or one year from the date of the final order on appeal, revision or reference, if any, in respect thereof whichever is later. Explanation: The expression final order on appeal, revision or reference includes an order passed by the Supreme Court under Article 32, 132, 133, 136 or 137, or by the High Court under Article 226 or 227 of the Constitution.
Section 17 of Amending Act contains transitional provisions for deeming and validation consequent upon deletion of sub-sections (4) and (5) of section 8-A and substitution of section 29-A.
Section 17 provides that amounts already deposited under section 8-A(4) shall be deemed to be under new section 29-A.
Dispute relates to amount wrongly realised by dealer as sales tax from customer.

legal_issues.text: Whether State Legislature has competence to enact section 29-A (substituted) and section 17 of Amending Act requiring deposit of amount wrongly realised as sales tax into Government Treasury, under any entry in List II or List III of Seventh Schedule.
Whether section 17 is dependent on and cannot exist independently of section 15 (substituting section 29-A).

petitioner_arguments.text: Impugned provisions covered by entry 54 List II as ancillary or incidental to collection of tax legitimately due.
Impugned law covered by entry 7 List III (contracts).
Impugned law relates to trust under entry 10 List III.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 10 List III Seventh Schedule; Section 3 Indian Trusts Act, 1882

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in holding section 17 unconstitutional as it is ancillary to section 15.

court_reasoning.text: High Court correctly held sections unconstitutional; section 17 dependent on section 15 and shares its fate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Section 15 principal, section 17 ancillary and linked.

court_reasoning.text: New section 29-A obliges dealer to deposit wrongly realised amount as sales tax into Treasury notwithstanding no liability as tax; amount held in trust for person from whom realised; refundable on claim with time limit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Amount not sales tax, not covered by entry 54 List II.

court_reasoning.text: Argument that provision ancillary to entry 54 rejected following Abdul Quader: Legislature cannot provide for payment to Government of amount not exigible as tax merely because collected as tax.

Approved observations in Ashoka Marketing Ltd. v. State of Bihar: Provision compelling payment of erroneously collected amount not incidental to levy under entry 54; mere device cannot defeat Constitution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Quoted Shah J.: Cannot regard as incidental to taxing power.

court_reasoning.text: Not covered by entries 6, 7, 13 List III (contracts etc.); rejected as in Ashoka Marketing.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power does not extend to recovery of amount dealer not entitled to collect.

court_reasoning.text: Not a law relating to trusts under entry 10 List III; mere use of word 'trust' insufficient; trust defined in Indian Trusts Act as obligation annexed to property ownership.
court_reasoning.key_observation: In pith and substance, not relating to trusts.

holdings.text: Sections 29-A (substituted by s.15 Amending Act) and 17 of U.P. Sales Tax Amendment and Validation Act, 1971 unconstitutional and ultra vires State Legislature.
High Court's view on interdependence of s.15 and s.17 correct.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Sales Tax v. Ganga Sugar Corporation Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Held s.8A(4) ultra vires relying on Abdul Quader.

precedents_cited.case_name: Abdul Quader and Co. v. Sales Tax Officer, Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Invalidated similar provision; amount collected as tax but not exigible cannot be directed to be paid to Govt under ancillary power to entry 54 List II.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ashoka Marketing Ltd. v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar provisions in Bihar Sales Tax Act (s.20A) unconstitutional; not incidental to entry 54; rejected entries 6,7,13 List III.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Provisions for deposit of realised tax amounts; s.8A(4)(5) omitted; s.29A substituted.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Sales Tax Amendment and Validation Act, 1971
statutes_cited.relevance: Omitted s.8A(4)(5); substituted s.29A; transitional validation; held unconstitutional.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Taxation Amendment Act, 1969 (U.P. Act 11 of 1969)
Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Legislative competence for sales tax and trusts/contracts; no power to enact impugned provisions.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Trusts Act, 1882
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of trust; impugned law not relating to trusts.

statutes_cited.name: Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Similar provision invalidated in Abdul Quader.

outcome.summary: Appeal by certificate against Allahabad High Court judgment upholding unconstitutionality of s.29-A and s.17 of Amending Act dismissed; Supreme Court agreed with High Court, holding provisions ultra vires lacking legislative competence.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellants; upheld High Court's declaration of unconstitutionality.

key_quotes.text: "We do not think that the ambit of ancillary or incidental power goes to the extent of permitting Legislature to provide that though the amount collected-may be wrongly-by way of tax is not exigible under the law as made under the relevant taxing entry, it shall still be paid over to Government, as if it were a tax."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Abdul Quader, rejecting ancillary power argument.

key_quotes.text: "A provision which enables the dealer to pass on the liability for payment of tax is incidental to legislation for sales tax. But we are unable to hold that a provision, under which a dealer is called upon to pay to the State an amount which has been collected by him on a representation... is a provision incidental to the power to levy tax..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Ashoka Marketing (Shah J.), holding similar provision not incidental to entry 54.

key_quotes.text: "A mere device cannot be permitted to defeat the provision of the Constitution by clothing the claim in the form of a demand for depositing the money with the State which the dealer has collected, but which he was not entitled to collect."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Ashoka Marketing, characterizing impugned provision as unconstitutional device.
